tutorial.title: League Games
tutorial.descriptionContent: Group related variables into objects to create a team with players

executableContent.instructions:
We'll write some code that keeps track of a team's roster.

The first three variables look like they relate to the same object, a player. So let's group them.

1. Create a new empty object named `player`.  Use `const`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions: We've created some variables to help you get started. The plan is to group the related ones into objects. Have a look!

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
In an object, we have properties with values. Let's put the player's name into the object as a property.

1. Inside the object, add a `playerName` property.
2. Give the property the value `"Leo"`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add more properties to the `player` object.

1. Add a `goalsScored` property and set its value to `4`.
2.  Add a `gamesPlayed` property and set its value to `2`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The player needs to be in a team. 

Hence, let's create a `team` object.

1. Create a second object called `team`. Use `const`

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use the keyword `const` and the object name, followed by an equals sign, curly braces, and a semicolon.

executableContent.instructions:
Similar to the player, we will convert the variables `teamName`, `numberPlayers` and `varsity` into object properties. 

1. Turn the variables `teamName`, `numberPlayers`, and `varsity` into properties of the object `team`. 
2. Remember to add commas between properties.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have our objects ready, we don't need the variables.

1. Clean up the code by manually removing/deleting the variables as they've been converted into properties.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Our `player` object is a member of the team. 

Let's add a new property in the `team` object for members.

1. Add a `member` property to the `team` object and give it the value `player`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Use `property: value` inside the object's curly braces to set the object properties. 

Don't forget the commas between properties.

executableContent.instructions:
Our team is set. Let's display the `team` object and check out our team!

1. Display the `team` object in the console.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `console.log` to display anything in the console.
